items.content_html: Convinced myself to get up and do a bit of strength training this AM. On the one hand it’s like, oh, hey, hello, those are muscles I never actually activate that way when I’m running. What fun and interesting feelings! Ow! Fun! Ow! On the other hand, ugh, it’s not really fun, huh. I think I haven’t found the thing I want to do that I can feel like I’m making progress at in tangible ways, the same way I can feel like I’m getting better at running, either by going farther or faster. (Or just more, uh, funner.)

items.content_html:
Once upon a time I was a math guy.

Like, when I went to college, I was going to double major in English and Math, which is crazy to think about today. It did not go well! I did not make the transition from high school math to advanced math successfully, in part because it got real hard‚Äînothing can quite prepares you for the part where math suddenly stops seeming to have much to do with numbers. (It gets weird, doesn’t it?) Also in part because I discovered writing and realized I really wanted to do writing. (Or at least I really wanted to “be a writer,” which is different, of course, isn’t it?) And also in part because, well, girls. (An uninteresting guy has gotta have something to write about, right?)

I managed to escape college with a math minor, making way for a creative writing minor. Now it’s *mumbles unintelligently* years later and sure I still write, sort of, and sure some aspects of mathematical thinking inform my ability to make computers do things, but, like…I don’t know. I wonder how much college Darby would recognize adult-with-mortgage Darby. If the two would have much to talk about.

My dreams are far more idle these days.

Once in a while something tweaks and fidgets some old dormant strain of me and I catch myself wondering how much of those old pathways still exist, how much they dangle into empty but inviting space; if I picked up a calculus book, today, if I looked at the texts that came next, could I make heads or tails of any of it? I have no time for it, I have other things I can actually do in the little time I have, and yet some diluted flavor of curiosity lingers, even after all these years.

I also still think a bit about the notion from my one chaos theory class that you’ll eventually get everywhere when you run the same equation long enough and I suppose that would be more metaphorically informative today if I had an actual idea where I was trying to get to with this kind of line of thinking. And also I’ve probably got that whole concept wrong, because, well, yeah. Math got hard.

items.content_html: Being less conservative than usual in my back-to-running plan this time out means jumping right back into back-to-back Monday-Tuesday runs; I was very cautious about that on my original back-to-running session earlier this year, after taking seven-ish weeks off, but I’m hoping that after only three-ish weeks off this time I can start at a slightly higher baseline. So: did three miles yesterday and today and definitely felt like I was working for it this morning‚Äînote to self: those dining room chairs aren’t the friendliest choices for extended sitting when writing the night before‚Äîbut the good news is, I made it, and, sure, while I’m feeling a touch creakier than I’d prefer right now, I’m also not absolutely miserable, it all kind of feels like it’s in the acceptable bounds of reason. Onward, etc.

items.title: My personal Onion headline slash running mantra üèÉ
items.content_html:
“This Moron Thinks He’s Still Going to Run a Marathon Someday!” is the Onion headline I’ve been mentally drafting about myself as I’ve started restarting running yet again the last few days. It’s funny because it’s true!

Look, saying this year has disappointed only represents part of the story. I’ve had some low lows but also some high highs. Getting knocked out of training for this last race has felt particularly unfair‚ÄîI don’t even think the injury was running related!‚Äîbut then also I’ve has some pleasing builds and surprising gains along the way this year. There’s been enough of all the good stuff so that when I start finding myself thinking that maybe I’m done with this whole phase of my life I soon thereafter start thinking, naw, I’m not.

So, now, I’ve got three months to go, this year, and while I won’t make my race goal, I’m thinking maybe, maybe, I can still make it back up to the 13 mile long run marker, on my own? Maybe. It’s not a race but it’s still a goal and I like goals. And then from there if nothing’s breaking too violently or creaking too loudly maybe next year it’s just time to go for broke and try for a full marathon. I’m clearly not getting younger, I guess. And maybe I’ve got all the nonsense out of my way this past year, maybe. Or not! I don’t know. Who knows.

The good news I’ve started back up again and I’m two runs in and instead of my usual super slow start I’ve convinced myself that three mile runs are still in my range and though they’ve certainly taken a bit of do-I-even-run-bro effort to finish up I don’t feel like I’m going to immediately die in the aftermath, so that’s good. Have to start (again) somewhere, in any event; I mean, big goals aside I just need to get through the next couple weeks and get back into a baseline basic swing of things, first and foremost.

items.content_html:
Saw The Creator Friday night.

It was interesting. I liked it. I didn‚Äôt love it. Solid slab of sci-fi action; some weird tonal inconsistencies and odd emotional beats.

Either way, I feel bad it‚Äôs probably going to be seen as a flop, because I don‚Äôt think I can handle the ‚Äúthis is why we don‚Äôt have original IP anymore‚Äù thinkpieces. Because I mean, as much as I love my franchisey nonsense, I‚Äôm also still hungry for new kinds of nonsense. It‚Äôd be nice to have both.

items.title: ‚Ä¶to Brand New Cherry Flavor üìö
items.content_html: And on the subject of “things that come to mind when I search around online using the word ‘cherry’” I was just reminded of the (excellent) Netflix series Brand New Cherry Flavor which in turn reminded me of the novel the series was based on, a novel I haven’t read, and which novel is out of print and (shockingly) hard to find physical copies of, out there in the world. (Biblio has some multiple-hundred dollar copies up for sale, which, no thank you.) Finally just thought to check the local libraries and while the Lakewood Public Library doesn’t have it the Cleveland Public Library does have a couple copies floating around. So I’ve got a hold out on that. I’m imagining it will make for a good October read. üìö

items.title: From Cherry Glazerr‚Ä¶ üé∂
items.content_html: There’s been a string of weeks featuring new albums that are, ahem, relevant to my interests. Today’s batch includes a new Cherry Glazerr album. I was deeply, into Stuffed & Ready for a long time; one of those albums that really got its hooks into me and refused to let go. Too soon to tell yet if the new one will reach that level for me, but, so far, I’m into it; I like how it somewhat surprisingly sounds like a natural extension of what they did on that previous album, but with all these new sounds and moods pulled in. üé∂

items.title: Oppenheimer, well after the fact üçø
items.content_html:
I’ve been listening to the Blank Check podcast a bit lately. It’s fun.

Yesterday I finally listened to their Oppenheimer episode and aside from getting me really excited about that movie again (for the record, I think that film was monumental) I realized that after seeing that movie opening weekend I let it wash over me in the days that followed but somehow avoided engagement with most of the resulting discourse around it; instead, I mostly stewed in my own thoughts about it. There were some unavoidable, and reductive, nuggets of talk that got tossed in my path, of course‚Äîconcern that the movie didn’t show the actual bombings, for example, or that the movie didn’t deal enough with Oppenheimer’s feelings of guilt, I guess? Hearing some of those things discussed in some nuance was intriguing; hearing some of my own unspoken thoughts reflected back at me in this little audio time capsule was, well, I hesitate to say validating, so let’s just say also intriguing.

I’m looking forward to watching that movie again some day, even though I know it won’t rival my unduplicatable opening weekend front-row Imax experience. I also want to go back and watch a bunch of other Christopher Nolan movies that I haven’t seen in a while.

(Also, can I get Tenet back in theaters? I thought it was great, but I wish I could see it again, you know, the “right” way.)
items.content_text:
I've been listening to [the Blank Check podcast](https://www.blankcheckpod.com/) a bit lately. It's fun.

Yesterday I finally listened to their _Oppenheimer_ episode and aside from getting me really excited about that movie again (for the record, I think that film was monumental) I realized that after seeing that movie opening weekend I let it wash over me in the days that followed but somehow avoided engagement with most of the resulting discourse around it; instead, I mostly stewed in my own thoughts about it. There were some unavoidable, and reductive, nuggets of talk that got tossed in my path, of course‚Äîconcern that the movie didn't show the actual bombings, for example, or that the movie didn't deal enough with Oppenheimer's feelings of guilt, I guess? Hearing some of those things discussed in some nuance was intriguing; hearing some of my own unspoken thoughts reflected back at me in this little audio time capsule was, well, I hesitate to say validating, so let's just say _also_ intriguing. 

I'm looking forward to watching that movie again some day, even though I know it won't rival my unduplicatable opening weekend front-row Imax experience. I also want to go back and watch a bunch of other Christopher Nolan movies that I haven't seen in a while.

(Also, can I get _Tenet_ back in theaters? I thought it was great, but I wish I could see it again, you know, the "right" way.)

items.title: Them DVD.com Feels üçø üé¨ üìÄ
items.content_html:
In other news, entering the very very very final week of DVD.com (Netflix DVD!) has me feeling weird feels.

I’ve been feeling weird feels about the whole concept of “endings” for a while now anyway. Probably specifically since watching the movie Aniara. (Which I watched on a rental disc, thank you very much.)

Seeing semifrequent comments out there in the wild about folks not even owning disc players anymore at a time when I’m mourning the loss of a service that has provided incredibly convenient rental access to media often only available in physical formats is…kind of a lot.

We’ve got quite a backlog of physical discs from Criterion and other boutique labels on our shelves, that have been waiting in the wings while I’ve tried to hammer through as much of the DVD.com queue as possible.

I mean, not that getting through the queue was ever a possibility‚ÄîI’ve been actually increasing its length this last month, for reasons‚Äîbut it’s been fun to watch through lots of stuff for all the reasons I’ve liked getting stuff through that channel. Stuff we’d be renting one-offs of digitally, or just getting more cheaply via the dvd service, or just getting it on physical format because it’s not available any other way, or because as a discovery service it’s been an absolutely delightful way to chuck seemingly random stuff into the queue and then, well, you just kind of watch it, because, what the heck, why not?

There’s certainly other ways to get this stuff, in the future. Buying more stuff. Our local library systems are good. I’ve signed up for a Scarecrow Video account which will probably get some use.

Still, though: those red envelopes folks thought were already consigned to the dustbin of history, finally actually being consigned to the dustbin of history…it’s a thing, isn’t it.

items.title: On (Not) Running
items.content_html:
About seven weeks ago I dropped out of my half-marathon training around the midpoint of the twelve-week plan. After weeks of struggling through various pains, I‚Äôd had enough. It sucked. Going into training, I thought I was in a really good place. And then I wasn‚Äôt.

Seven weeks is about the longest I‚Äôve taken off from running since 2021. That time I think I rage quit because I wasn‚Äôt having fun and I was running very poorly. That time I needed the mental break; this time I needed the physical break. I know both breaks were necessary. That first time I needed a hard reset. This time around, though, I mentally felt ready for anything, at a time when my body decided to give me the finger. I‚Äôve been striving toward the point where consistent, regular running was a natural part of my routine, so I could alternate progressing up toward new goals and floating back down to a solid, easy base. Needless to say, it did not work out like that.

I‚Äôm not trying to dwell on any of this. I do want to put a bow on it as I start to move on. Several times over the last month or so I‚Äôve sincerely toyed with the thought that maybe that was actually it, maybe I‚Äôm done now, maybe I just won‚Äôt go back.

ButI I‚Äôm going back. Just this week I started back up again at something like square one….one mile runs, that is! Which isn‚Äôt actually square one‚ÄîI‚Äôm still light-years beyond where I was when I started running in 2019. I do not want to take that for granted. Still, as eager as I am mentally to get back to long-as-heck weekend runs, I know it‚Äôs going to be a while and I know how important it is to ease back up to where I actually want to be.

And, yes, even just getting out there for fifteen minutes last night felt nice, like a taste of something that I know has been missing the last few weeks. I haven‚Äôt been idle since I stopped training. I mean, yes, I took a hard week off at the start, and last week was a low one, and I‚Äôve been a bit all over the place in the middle, but I have been trying to at least get up on the elliptical for some easier movement, and I‚Äôve also been once again trying to get into something resembling a regular strength routine, specifically body weight exercises targeting my leg muscles in an effort to give my knees some support. Finding things I actually don‚Äôt mind doing has been a nice turn and I know it‚Äôs important now to figure out how to keep that stuff going as I start to slide back into running. Making the time for it sucks but then not doing anything sucks even more, so.

Aaaaaand of course today I started marking out races and potential training start dates on my calendar, so…no pressure, of course, but also, it’s nice to feel like I have those goals back in front of me, still.

About seven weeks ago I dropped out of my half-marathon training around the midpoint of the twelve-week plan. After weeks of struggling through various pains, I‚Äôd had enough. It sucked. Going into training, I thought I was in a really good place. And then I wasn‚Äôt.

Seven weeks is about the longest I‚Äôve taken off from running since 2021. That time I think I rage quit because I wasn‚Äôt having fun and I was running very poorly. That time I needed the mental break; this time I needed the physical break. I know both breaks were necessary. That first time I needed a hard reset. This time around, though, I mentally felt ready for anything, at a time when my body decided to give me the finger. I‚Äôve been striving toward the point where consistent, regular running was a natural part of my routine, so I could alternate progressing up toward new goals and floating back down to a solid, easy base. Needless to say, it did not work out like that.

I‚Äôm not trying to dwell on any of this. I do want to put a bow on it as I start to move on. Several times over the last month or so I‚Äôve sincerely toyed with the thought that maybe that was actually it, maybe I‚Äôm done now, maybe I just won‚Äôt go back. 

ButI I‚Äôm going back. Just this week I started back up again at something like square one....one mile runs, that is! Which isn‚Äôt _actually_ square one‚ÄîI‚Äôm still light-years beyond where I was when I started running in 2019. I do not want to take that for granted. Still, as eager as I am mentally to get back to long-as-heck weekend runs, I know it‚Äôs going to be a while and I know how important it is to ease back up to where I actually want to be. 

And, yes, even just getting out there for fifteen minutes last night felt nice, like a taste of something that I know has been missing the last few weeks. I haven‚Äôt been idle since I stopped training. I mean, yes, I took a hard week off at the start, and last week was a low one, and I‚Äôve been a bit all over the place in the middle, but I have been trying to at least get up on the elliptical for some easier movement, and I‚Äôve also been once again trying to get into something resembling a regular strength routine, specifically body weight exercises targeting my leg muscles in an effort to give my knees some support. Finding things I actually don‚Äôt mind doing has been a nice turn and I know it‚Äôs important now to figure out how to keep that stuff going as I start to slide back into running. Making the time for it sucks but then not doing anything sucks even more, so.

Aaaaaand of course today I started marking out races and potential training start dates on my calendar, so...no pressure, of course, but also, it's nice to feel like I have those goals back in front of me, still.

items.title: March Running Music üèÉ
items.content_html:
I‚Äôm continuing to do a very silly thing this year that I described here.

My February list is here and my March list is below. Here’s a playlist of tracks from it. As usual: probably not a good list to try to run to.

  1. Con Todo El Mundo by Khruangbin. (Chill vibes.)
  2. The Head on the Door by The Cure. (Kind of a weird choice of a Cure album to run to. But then I guess any Cure album would be kind of a weird choice for a run.)
  3. Mariner by Cult of Luna and Julie Christmas. (I’ve gotten loosely more into heavier music and metal music over the last few years. This one is an absolute gem; I like other albums by Cult of Luna, but this one’s so good. I’ve a particular fondness for metal with lady singers who actually, like, sing; that contrast is an absolute delight. No offense intended to the stereotypical metal male scream-style vocal, which I’ve come to mind less over the years‚Äîit has its place and purpose for me‚Äîbut stuff like this is just so my jam. Hitting the end of this album and not feeling a bit like you’re doing the most epic run ever is probably out of the question. I mean, if you’re into that sort of thing.)
  4. Dive by Tycho. (The chillest vibes.)
  5. Every Open Eye by Chvrches. (I might have to throw a loophole clause out there for this one; I think the run was too bad to warrant keeping this wonderful album off the list for the rest of the year. If nothing else the back-to-back attack of “Playing Dead” and “Bury It” would probably show up on any time-to-get-it-done running mix I ever make.)
  6. The Heart is a Monster by Failure. (Good long run vibes; it’s a whole journey. It’s also, weirdly, the only Failure album I’ve really gotten into. I didn’t know them during their initial run and so I’m not sure why I threw this on when it originally came out but I got into it pretty hard; nothing else since has quite clicked for me and while I know I’ve gone back to their older stuff to check it out, this is the one I keep coming back to whenever I need whatever it is they give me.)
  7. A Gaze Among Them by Big|Brave. (More heavy vibes with good lady vocals.)
  8. Nightstand by Tancred. (More chill vibes.)
  9. In Sides by Orbital. (I mean, this is probably, categorically, one of the best long run albums in my rotation.)
  10. Little Red by Katy B. (She’s so good.)

There’s fewer albums this time in part because training’s been messier than usual this month and in part because I started shuffling in some DJ mixes from Soundcloud on race pace and tempo nights.

I have a somewhat curated playlist of elctronic/techno mixes here that I can pretty reliably hit shuffle on and get a good running mix‚Äîmostly because all those come from a much longer and less curated list I’ve been shuffling mixes out of for a while; the ones that feel good get promoted to the public list. I’ve come to like reserving these mixes for “pace” runs, which seem to call for a more immersive flow. They also do tend to make me want to try to go a little harder than I usually do. It’s all a whole thing, isn’t it.

items.title: Regarding Drafts
items.content_html:
Like a good Micro.blogger, I’m finally playing around with Drafts. I think I like it! I have some thoughts. (Which I’m writing up in Drafts, of course.)

  • Having text I feel some need to put down, and being able to do so without the mental overhead of thinking about which app or which folder or which collection or which method is appropriate to that text, is more refreshing than I expected.
  • At first I thought the lack of folders or whatever inside Drafts was weird, but now I think I get it; tagging things is fine, if I need to, if I actually make use of it, otherwise, it’s just a running log of text things, and this is not the place where they’ll ultimately live, if they need to live on‚Äîthey’ll turn into blog posts or emails or Obsidian or Notion docs or whatever they need to, and then eventually out of Drafts. (Or they can just float around in the archive until the end of time. That’s fine.)
  • All of which is to say: I understand now when folks say this is the first app they go to when they have to do some text. Still early to tell if it will be the same for me, but I like the idea of it.
  • That said I haven’t really set up integrations much yet. No posting to micro.blog from here or sending to Obsidian or whatever, mostly because I think I need to pay the subscription fee to be able to edit the steps for those, to make those all work, right? I’ll probably wind up paying but if I find out I’m not using this in two weeks maybe I actually won’t.
  • I’m getting more into using app-specific system hotkeys in MacOS, so like I have Keysmith installed now so I can do some specific browser stuff, and I’ve got a hotkey for iTerm set up, and now I’ve got the new Drafts hotkeys, and I kind of wish I had a whole separate row of function keys on my keyboard I could label to all these specific tasks, so I can lose the mental “uhm okay hang on option shift what again?” baggage.
  • I’m wondering what other cool tricks I should know about here. There’s a bunch of tips online but I’m not sure how much I actually want to make use of yet. (I started drafting a note about ‘ways I use text"…now I guess I have to remember to update it when I think of other ways I use text.)
  • I’m wondering now if I might actually want to jettison Notion from my life. I don’t use it for a lot, I guess, and I guess there’s specific ways I do use it; and I guess for sharing purposes I like the feel of it more than Google Docs. That said…I don’t like the “HEY HEY HEY USE OUR AI!!!” approach they have in place. Because I never want to use AI to write text. And just getting rid of something to make room for this new thing might not be the worst thing in the world to do.
  • Is there, like, a “zen mode” here, on the desktop app? I’m typing this right now with all the sidebars and menu bars and everything open, and I wonder if there’s a key to just hide everything but the note I’m writing (without having to manually turn each thing off and on again). I figured out how to create a super minimal experience in Obsidian which is nice for writing; I’d like something similar here. (That’s not a Workspace thing, is it?)
  • Okay, I lied: I just added the post to Micro.blog extension. If you can read this, I guess it worked!

items.title: Race training update üèÉ
items.content_html:
I’m midway through the current half-marathon training cycle and it’s been kind of a mess! High highs and low lows.

After doing some solid base training leading into the 12 week run-up, I got knocked out by a cold after one run on week one, and missed three runs in a row that week. In the rush to try to catch back up to the plan I think I borderline pushed too hard, which resulted in various leg/knee/ankle pains that all kind of straddled the fence between “Eh, you’re fine, push through this and you’ll be okay!” and “Eh, you should get yourself poured into a body cast and quit running forever, old man.”

I’ve generally opted to push through, with some modifications of the plan along the way, including skipping most of my interval runs, in an effort to try to both keep moving forward while also scaling back in response to what my body was telling me. After playing catch-up week two, I got through weeks three through five alright, capping out at a new-for-me most-miles-in-a-week week. I’ve even generally kept up with the tempo runs and race pace runs, which has been nice.

Then last week was another rough miss. I felt okay enough to take a stab at doing an interval run and to my surprise I ran the intervals much faster than I’d anticipated. I’m not going to lie: it felt pretty awesome. To continue the not-lying: I did not feel pretty awesome the next couple days! I wound up skipping my next two weekday runs in order to let things settle back down, before picking back up with my weekend long run on Saturday, which maybe went better than expected?

Now we’re on to week seven. I had a tempo run scheduled for last night, but I swapped in an easy run in its place, though my “easy” pace in this case crept up a bit as the run went on. That said, it generally felt okay, and dare I say it even felt like maybe I was finally feeling like I was having a little fun with running again? I’m sure the warmer weather had something to do with that. (First short-sleeves run of the year!) All things going well, this will be my next most-miles-in-a-week week, though, of course, at this point, who knows.

Overall, I can’t say I’m feeling entirely optimistic, nor can I say I’m pessimistic, either, really. What I guess I feel like is someone who isn’t quite sure whether he’s properly and adequately pushing the limits of what he’s capable of, or whether he’s being a real big stubborn dumb-dumb because he put some money down on a race experience and he doesn’t want to miss out. On the one hand I’m telling myself I’m not going down without a fight; on the other hand I’m wondering if maybe I’m losing sight of the forest for the trees. Either way, I’m not quitting without a really compelling reason.

items.title: February Running Music Report üé∂ üèÉ
items.content_html:
I’m continuing to do a very silly thing this year that I described here. I rounded up my January listening here; below is my February list. (Don’t point out that it’s almost the end of March. I know. I know…)

Here’s a playlist of tracks from these albums. As with the January playlist, I might not run to this. (But actually, I might! I don’t know.)

  1. Nova by Sylvaine. (By all rights I should have saved the wintry Nordic metal for, I don’t know, July. But sometimes you’ve gotta steer into the skid.)
  2. Versions of Modern Performance by Horsegirl. (I feel like there’s this round of girl-singers-doing-retro-90s-stuff bands going around right now and I’m generally here for it.)
  3. Star by Belly. (Hat tip to ‚ÄúWhirring‚Äù by The Joy Formidable for inspiring a big finish at the end of this run.)
  4. Ethereality by Pastel Ghost. (I don’t know if it’s the right comparison but I kind of have this in that same sort of warmly chill synthy pop realm as Purity Ring. If I could line up the right bands I could probably easily do a whole chill month’s runs to acts like this.)
  5. Warmth by Blondes. (Remaining a sucker for a good weather album title joke. It was not warm out there that night.)
  6. Cosmogramma by Flying Lotus. (Not my favorite album of his, but felt like the right one to try a run to.)
  7. Adam & Eve by Catherine Wheel. (Okay, so, I’m a huge Catherine Wheel fan. Top to bottom, their entire discography, love it, love them, love their music. If they ever got back together I would be torn between selling plasma to get front row seats and wanting nothing to do with it because you shouldn’t see your heroes get old and grab cash, right? Right. Anyway! This album has been one of the ones that’s most grown on me in the last, uh, let’s not count how many years I’ve been listening to them now? Anyway: it’s a shockingly amazing running album. It’s basically an album full of upward-lifting swells, one after the other, and I feel like every time I’ve listened to it while running, I’ve run a little bit quicker, a little bit lighter, I’ve just felt a little better. It’s picked me up and carried me a bit further with each pass. And…now I don’t get to listen to it during a run again this year. Boo! Bummer! Whose stupid idea was this plan, anyway/ Anyway. Your mileage may vary. And…yup, I just killed the “your mileage may vary” joke in the February list, didn’t I? Crud. It’s going to be a long year.)
  8. Purple by Baroness. (It was a little cruel, popping this one one, for what was intended to be an easy run. It’s also probably not the first choice folks have for favorite Baroness album but I don’t even care because this album slams so good.)
  9. Screen Violence by Chvrches. (Trying to parcel out their albums over the year. Not sure I’m going to do a great job at it.)
  10. A Cricket in Times Square by A Cricket in Times Square. (A secret classic by a band you’ve never heard of. I wish they’d stayed together; they should have been huge. That said: this album is amazing.)
  11. 13 Tales From Urban Bohemia by The Dandy Warhols. (Good long run album, actually. A little all over the place!)
  12. Lobes by We Are Scientists. (Hey, these guys are still around! And they’re still fun. Fun! Also of note: I started downshifting pretty hard this week, ahead of race training. I’m questioning that choice today.)
  13. Memory by Vivian Girls. (Easily one of my top 10 bands.)
  14. Far by Regina Spektor. (Is it a weird choice for my favorite Regina Spektor album? I don’t know. Don’t care. It’s wonderful.)
  15. Melody‚Äôs Echo Chamber by Melody‚Äôs Echo Chamber. (Psychy dreamy rock pop? Yes please.)
  16. Detrimentalist by Venetian Snares. (I was starting to come down with what would be at least a week-long head cold and this album helped me power through my first official training run of race training this cycle, with a 30 minute tempo run. Then everything fell apart…)

Total album count’s now at 33 albums, assuming I haven’t missed anything. Now we’re starting to get into the thing where managing this mess is kind of a weird experience. I’m trying to keep my notes app list updated after every run, and I’m periodically trying to chuck more albums into the list, because it feels like every time I open the list I’m like “naw” to everything I have slated for potential runs. And just, using a todo list in the notes app is a bit not-quite-right-but-close-enough for this. Anyways.

I rounded up [my January listening here](https://darby3.micro.blog/2023/02/01/january-running-music.html); below is my February list. (Don't point out that it's almost the end of March. I know. I know...)

Here's [a playlist of tracks](https://tidal.com/browse/playlist/35a74307-2941-4a5f-b44c-46fdbba56917) from these albums. As with [the January playlist](https://darby3.micro.blog/2023/02/04/threw-together-a.html), I might not run to this. (But actually, I might! I don't know.)

1. ***Nova* by Sylvaine**. (By all rights I should have saved the wintry Nordic metal for, I don't know, July. But sometimes you've gotta steer into the skid.)
2. ***Versions of Modern Performance* by Horsegirl**. (I feel like there's this round of girl-singers-doing-retro-90s-stuff bands going around right now and I'm generally here for it.)
3. ***Star* by Belly**. (Hat tip to ‚ÄúWhirring‚Äù by The Joy Formidable for inspiring a big finish at the end of this run.)
4. ***Ethereality* by Pastel Ghost**. (I don't know if it's the right comparison but I kind of have this in that same sort of warmly chill synthy pop realm as Purity Ring. If I could line up the right bands I could probably easily do a whole chill month's runs to acts like this.)
5. ***Warmth* by Blondes**. (Remaining a sucker for a good weather album title joke. It was *not* warm out there that night.)
6. ***Cosmogramma* by Flying Lotus**. (Not my favorite album of his, but felt like the right one to try a run to.)
7. ***Adam & Eve* by Catherine Wheel**. (Okay, so, I'm a huge Catherine Wheel fan. Top to bottom, their entire discography, love it, love them, love their music. If they ever got back together I would be torn between selling plasma to get front row seats and wanting nothing to do with it because you shouldn't see your heroes get old and grab cash, right? Right. Anyway! This album has been one of the ones that's most grown on me in the last, uh, let's not count how many years I've been listening to them now? Anyway: it's a shockingly amazing running album. It's basically an album full of upward-lifting swells, one after the other, and I feel like every time I've listened to it while running, I've run a little bit quicker, a little bit lighter, I've just felt a little *better*. It's picked me up and carried me a bit further with each pass. And...now I don't get to listen to it during a run again this year. Boo! Bummer! Whose stupid idea was this plan, anyway/ Anyway. Your mileage may vary. And...yup, I just killed the "your mileage may vary" joke in the February list, didn't I? Crud. It's going to be a long year.)
8. ***Purple* by Baroness**. (It was a little cruel, popping this one one, for what was intended to be an easy run. It's also probably not the first choice folks have for favorite Baroness album but I don't even care because this album slams so good.)
9. ***Screen Violence* by Chvrches**. (Trying to parcel out their albums over the year. Not sure I'm going to do a great job at it.)
10. ***A Cricket in Times Square* by A Cricket in Times Square**. (A secret classic by a band you've never heard of. I wish they'd stayed together; they should have been huge. That said: this album is amazing.)
11. ***13 Tales From Urban Bohemia* by The Dandy Warhols**. (Good long run album, actually. A little all over the place!)
12. ***Lobes* by We Are Scientists**. (Hey, these guys are still around! And they're still fun. Fun! Also of note: I started downshifting pretty hard this week, ahead of race training. I'm questioning that choice today.)
13. ***Memory* by Vivian Girls**. (Easily one of my top 10 bands.)
14. ***Far* by Regina Spektor**. (Is it a weird choice for my favorite Regina Spektor album? I don't know. Don't care. It's wonderful.)
15. ***Melody‚Äôs Echo Chamber* by Melody‚Äôs Echo Chamber**. (Psychy dreamy rock pop? Yes please.)
16. ***Detrimentalist* by Venetian Snares**. (I was starting to come down with what would be at least a week-long head cold and this album helped me power through my first official training run of race training this cycle, with a 30 minute tempo run. Then everything fell apart...)

Total album count's now at 33 albums, assuming I haven't missed anything. Now we're starting to get into the thing where managing this mess is kind of a weird experience. I'm trying to keep my notes app list updated after every run, and I'm periodically trying to chuck more albums into the list, because it feels like every time I open the list I'm like "naw" to everything I have slated for potential runs. And just, using a todo list in the notes app is a bit not-quite-right-but-close-enough for this. Anyways.

items.title: Race training has been a mess. So is this update! üèÉ
items.content_html:
I was doing swell before training started. Thought I had set a nice comfortable base. But, getting knocked out of training on week one after one run by a head cold was…not great. I got back out there week two, and actually hit all the planned miles on week three, but scrambling back up to this point, where I’m not just above my pre-training base, did me no favors. Now I’m fighting through some pains that have me thrashing between “I should quit. I’m being dumb. Ugh.” and “I’m okay. This is just something to power through. …Ugh.”

So, going forward…I don’t now. I’m already off plan so I’ve got room to adapt. Like, I missed week two’s interval run, and will likely replace tonight’s planned intervals with an easy run, which I’m sad about because I was looking forward to doing those again, but I feel like it’s the smarter choice to keep things easier right now.

My thought is, even if all my runs become easy runs, I’d like to try to keep my mileage at or around where the plan would have me, which was still a bit of an ambitious goal, just that in itself. But maybe that’s all the stretch I need right now‚Äîif I can get to the finish line while letting go of race time goals but also being able to say I just got more miles done during training, that’s still something to take with me and feel glad for.

On the flip side, of course, if I need to quit, while it will suck, I will quit. I really don’t want to, but, if it’s not in the cards, it’s not in the cards. Still: I’m hoping I don’t need to. I think I’ll learn a lot from this coming week, which at least in terms of mileage is pretty close to week three; I’m swapping out the interval run for an easy run of the same distance, and I’m hoping to do my race pace training run Thursday, but that’s entirely flexible, too. We’ll see what happens as I continue to adjust. One day, one week at a time, right now.

items.title: And we are off... üèÉ
items.content_html:
Officially kicked off training for my next half marathon last night with a 30 minute tempo run. Considering I was feeling slightly under the weather all day, I wasn’t sure I’d do the run at all, let alone do it well, and yet…I pretty much nailed exactly what I set out to do.

My training plan this time out is both more ambitious and a bit more fun, I think. The fun part comes both from increased variety of runs, but also from the fact that‚Äîhaving been through one full training plan so far, having made it to the finish line once, having convinced myself that, yes, I can actually literally do this (even in unexpectedly frigid, un-trained-for weather!), having set a nice base since I got back to consistent running again over the last seven weeks…I think I can loosen up a bit this time, and focus even more on enjoying the process. Not that I didn’t enjoy the process the first time through! I wouldn’t have made it to the end if I hadn’t, and I still think the process itself, the couple dozen runs that go into it, is more important than that one flashy run at the end. But, like, now, I can enjoy the process of seeing what else I can do, knowing what I’ve done already, knowing I’ve still got plenty of room to improve, or even just grow. If that makes sense.

I’m up to four runs a week, over the three runs a week I did in the fall; I’ve got a mix of tempo, interval, race pace, and easy/long runs planned. That variety is going to be nice, but also, and I think most importantly, I have very fixed target paces in mind for all these kinds of runs, unlike last time, when I pretty much had no idea what paces to target for anything.

So like for my “race pace” I’m targeting a 2:15 half marathon goal, or 10:17/mile, which, at least right now, feels like a doable stretch. My tempo pace I’m basing off a somewhat aspirational 60 minute 10k goal, or 9:39/mile. (I know I have at least one of these in me, but focusing on trying to achieve it in reality hasn’t worked out yet.)

For both of these, I’ve set my watch to give me a +/- 30 second range on either side of these. I’m not good at sticking to specific paces on pure feel, and it just feels like a good idea to have a comfortable amount of wiggle room to play with each time out, hopefully without the watch yelling at me too much. I’m also measuring tempo runs in time, not distance, which is interesting, as basically all my runs forever now have been based on distance. Last night I did thirty minutes; I’ll get up to 45 at my peak.

On the outer extremes, my slow/easy pace is trying to keep things roughly slower than 11:00/mile, while my interval pace is to try my best to leave Back to the Future Delorean-style flame trails behind me, which should mean down below 9:00/mile. We’ll see, though. All my intervals will be quarter mile runs followed by quarter mile light jogs (or even walks), starting at four reps and going up to seven near the end.

So when I say last night went well, to my surprise, I mean my first two miles out I averaged out to within seconds of my 9:39/mile goal pace, and then edged toward about 10 seconds faster for the rest of run time. Considering I was worried about making it into the target range at all, I’ll take it!

Still a lot of easy running these first three weeks, with intervals and tempos alternating on Mondays; my long run Saturdays will start at 5 miles, adding a mile each week all the way up to 12. My max mileage weeks should top out at like 28 miles or so around that point, and I’ll be consistently above 20 for much of the plan, which is high for me, but I’m thinking doable, given a newfound commitment to making those easy runs actually easy. We’ll see what happens.

items.title: January Running Music Report üé∂ üèÉ
items.content_html:
I’m doing a very silly thing this year, which I described here.

Here’s a round-up of the albums I listened to during my runs in January. (I’m probably going to figure out a better way to present these lists. Eventually. Maybe!)

  1. The Physical World by Death From Above 1979. (Honestly I feel like I should get a re-do on this one since I picked it before I even had any idea what a dumb challenge I was facing this year.)
  2. Strange Little Birds by Garbage. (Garbage’s second-act albums have been consistently solid. I don’t know why I feel like that surprises me but it does.)
  3. Womb by Purity Ring. (I’m new to this band after I think confusing them for some other band I don’t want to like. This album is great.)
  4. Endure by Special Interest. (It was a good run.)
  5. See Through You by A Place to Bury Strangers. (I’ve lost track of them over the years, since the hayday of blog rock. Tuned back in with this newest album and, gee, it’s real good.)
  6. Once I Was An Eagle by Laura Marling. (This was the album I picked when I realized I was really going to have to start spreading my choices out to make it through the year’s project. Made for a good chill run. I like all the recurring motifs throughout this album.)
  7. Asiatisch by Fatima Al Qadiri. (While I want to like her music more than I think I actually do, this album did make running through the rain with the lights reflecting off the puddles feel like I was a background character in Bladerunner, and that was pretty great.)
  8. The Inheritors by James Holden. (I thought this would be more fun to run to than it actually was. It’s a great album, don’t get me wrong, but I think in retrospect it’s maybe a bit too electroproggyskronk to make for good running music.)
  9. All the Time by Jessy Lanza. (Summer vibes welcome.)
  10. Puberty 2 by Mitski. (I wasn’t ready to do intervals yet…but you kind of can’t not do a pseudo-interval or two to the chorus of “Best American Girl”.)
  11. Other Truths by Do Make Say Think. (I mean, when you can pair a four track album that’s forty minutes long to a four mile run…yeah.)
  12. Body Talk by Robyn. (I felt bad about giving this one up so early in the year but I really needed to take some sunshine on my run.)
  13. Reachy Prints by Plaid. (If you ever have the opportunity to go for a four mile run on a cold winter’s night when the snow is still clinging to the tree branches and the world looks like the inside of a fractal and you can pair it with music like Plaid’s, it’s worth it.)
  14. Time’s Arrow by Ladytron. (I ran a little too hard to this not-very-hard album. In any case, new Ladytron is always welcome.)
  15. Psychic by DARKSIDE. (Slowed me down, necessarily, nicely, to a neat groove. It’s not quite right but it has a certain “start of the long race” quality‚Äîgood keep it chill, keep it steady, dummy! music.)
  16. This is a Long Drive for Someone with Nothing to Think About by Modest Mouse. (It’s kind of amazing it took me this long to think of running to this one. There’s a nice three-act structure to the album, somewhat perfectly mirroring the warm-up/steady-stride/please-give-me-a-final-stretch-pick-up-and-carry-me-home structure of, at my paces, a seven mile rune. It was kind of perfect for that.)
  17. The Big Freeze by Laura Stevenson. (Laura Stevenson is wonderful. And I’m sorry I played this album almost entirely to use its title as a joke about the weather.)
items.content_text:
I'm doing a very silly thing this year, [which I described here](https://darby3.micro.blog/2023/01/09/184300.html). 

Here's a round-up of the albums I listened to during my runs in January. (I'm probably going to figure out a better way to present these lists. Eventually. Maybe!) 

1. ***The Physical World* by Death From Above 1979**. (Honestly I feel like I should get a re-do on this one since I picked it before I even had any idea what a dumb challenge I was facing this year.)
2. ***Strange Little Birds* by Garbage**. (Garbage's second-act albums have been consistently solid. I don't know why I feel like that surprises me but it does.)
3. ***Womb* by Purity Ring**. (I'm new to this band after I think confusing them for some other band I don't want to like. This album is great.)
4. ***Endure* by Special Interest**. (It was a good run.)
5. ***See Through You* by A Place to Bury Strangers**. (I've lost track of them over the years, since the hayday of blog rock. Tuned back in with this newest album and, gee, it's real good.)
6. ***Once I Was An Eagle* by Laura Marling**. (This was the album I picked when I realized I was really going to have to start spreading my choices out to make it through the year's project. Made for a good chill run. I like all the recurring motifs throughout this album.)
7. ***Asiatisch* by Fatima Al Qadiri**. (While I want to like her music more than I think I actually do, this album did make running through the rain with the lights reflecting off the puddles feel like I was a background character in *Bladerunner*, and that was pretty great.)

10. ***Puberty 2* by Mitski**. (I wasn't ready to do intervals yet...but you kind of can't not do a pseudo-interval or two to the chorus of "Best American Girl".)
11. ***Other Truths* by Do Make Say Think**. (I mean, when you can pair a four track album that's forty minutes long to a four mile run...yeah.)
12. ***Body Talk* by Robyn**. (I felt bad about giving this one up so early in the year but I really needed to take some sunshine on my run.)
13. ***Reachy Prints* by Plaid**. (If you ever have the opportunity to go for a four mile run on a cold winter's night when the snow is still clinging to the tree branches and the world looks like the inside of a fractal and you can pair it with music like Plaid's, it's worth it.)

15. ***Psychic* by DARKSIDE**. (Slowed me down, necessarily, nicely, to a neat groove. It's not *quite* right but it has a certain "start of the long race" quality‚Äîgood *keep it chill, keep it steady, dummy!* music.)
16. ***This is a Long Drive for Someone with Nothing to Think About* by Modest Mouse**. (It's kind of amazing it took me this long to think of running to this one. There's a nice three-act structure to the album, somewhat perfectly mirroring the warm-up/steady-stride/please-give-me-a-final-stretch-pick-up-and-carry-me-home structure of, at my paces, a seven mile rune. It was kind of perfect for that.)
17. ***The Big Freeze* by Laura Stevenson**. (Laura Stevenson is wonderful. And I'm sorry I played this album almost entirely to use its title as a joke about the weather.)

items.title: Current running plans üèÉ
items.content_html:
…which I am mostly throwing down in writing so I stop second-guessing myself.

I was getting into analysis paralysis over deciding between doing an April half marathon (which would probably have milder weather, but would mean shifting back into training mode like right now oh my god I have to go run 300 miles today) vs a May half marathon (which would give me more time to prepare, but in Cleveland, there’s a much higher chance the weather being real gross).

I’ve decided‚Äîor, I am deciding!‚Äîto go for the May race. Real hard to imagine running in potential 70-80 degree temperatures in four months! But, this means I can spend the next six weeks focusing on estasblishing a base, which is something I haven’t really consciously done in a long time. I’ve spent the last year pretty much rising up to races and then recovering from them (sometimes). Getting consistent for a bit feels like the right choice.

Right now I’m targeting four easy runs a week, totalling about 16‚Äì18 miles, maybe with some mildly faster runs or informal interval experiments to mix things up. That both feels high for me and also probably about right. (I keep reminding myself: “You’ve done a half marathon. You probably should be running more than you were when you first started out!") I’ve ramped up to this point a bit quickly the last few weeks, coming out of my December downtime, but now that I’m here, I think I can happily linger at this level for a bit.

Once those six weeks are up, and I’m hopefully feeling good, I’ll shift into a 12 week training plan. I’m working on a plan that’s a bit more ambitious than I tackled in the fall, complete with actual solid pace goals this time out. Still not planning on breaking any records (ever), but I think I can safely target a race time significantly lower faster than what I did in the fall. Unless of course the heat kills me dead the way the cold killed me dead in November.

items.content_html:
Here’s a bookmarklet for Micro.blog for the web, for use when scheduling posts. If you click the bookmarklet when you schedule a post (but before you click into the date field) you’ll have a date filled out that you can then modify as needed (to, say, add a couple hours to the time, or adjust the day while leaving the rest of the values alone).

javascript: (() => { const datePicker = document.querySelector("#input_date"); const curDate = datePicker.getAttribute("placeholder"); datePicker.setAttribute("value", curDate); datePicker.setAttribute("onclick", null); })();

Tested quickly in Firefox. It takes the date from the “placeholder” text, moves it to the “value” text, and then removes the handler that clears the date when you click into the field.

I have a previous bookmarklet for micro.blog here.
items.content_text:
Here's a bookmarklet for Micro.blog for the web, for use when scheduling posts. If you click the bookmarklet when you schedule a post (but before you click into the date field) you'll have a date filled out that you can then modify as needed (to, say, add a couple hours to the time, or adjust the day while leaving the rest of the values alone).

```
javascript: (() => { const datePicker = document.querySelector("#input_date"); const curDate = datePicker.getAttribute("placeholder"); datePicker.setAttribute("value", curDate); datePicker.setAttribute("onclick", null); })();
```

Tested quickly in Firefox. It takes the date from the "placeholder" text, moves it to the "value" text, and then removes the handler that clears the date when you click into the field. 

[I have a previous bookmarklet for micro.blog here](https://darby3.micro.blog/2022/10/04/throwing-a-code.html).

items.title: My Big Dumb Running and Music Challenge of 2023 üé∂ üèÉ
items.content_html:
I track and share my runs on Strava; on a whim, on my second run this year, I posted, in that run’s notes, the album I listened to during the run (Strange Little Birds by Garbage.) I did the same thing for the third run (Womb by Purity Ring) and the fourth run (Endure by Special Interest). Once I figured out what I ran to for the first run of the year (The Physical World by Death From Above 1979) I went back and added that, too.

Somewhere along the line, during one of these slow, easy runs, I started wondering: can I go the whole year without listening to the same album twice across any runs?

This is a dumb idea. It probably adds more stress to my life than I need. How am I going to track it? How am I going to pick new stuff if I make it to, like, December, or, heck, June? What happens if I use a favorite album too soon, or ruin it on a bad run? Does this actually result in a cool diary of what my year of running sounds like, or does sharing the fact that I do in fact sometimes listen to Taylor Swift absolutely destroy me in the public eye?

Still, it’s the kind of dumb seed of idea that finds fertile ground to develop into a big goofy plant of an idea when I’m out running, when I’m trying my hardest not to think about anything, and now I’m here with a bunch of thoughts and contraints around this absolutely pointless challenge I’m now apparently setting out for myself this year:

  • I’ll continue sharing the album on Strava, and possibly do monthly or quarterly round-up posts here. Until I forget. And then I won’t.
  • Loophole: if I’m craving something truly embarassing, I can redact it from the public records. But, like, as impeccably cool as my first four choices have been, it’ll pretty quickly become clear that, like, my music taste is far from impeccably cool.
  • Once I start the album, that’s it, it’s on the list. Plenty of runs won’t last long enough to cover entire albums. That’s fine. Also the album might just not work and I might have to click over to something else mid-run (see loophole below); the album still goes on the list.
  • Loophole: I’m only going to count the first album of any run. So like on long runs if I queue up multiple albums, anything I listen to after album number one doesn’t count. I’m probably mostly a deliriously unreceptive slate by that point anyway, so it really shouldn’t count.
  • That said, double albums? No two-disc loophole: it’s all one album. (So, yes, I’ll be saving stuff like The Fragile by Nine Inch Nails for seriously long runs.)
  • What happens when I’m running stays when I’m running; anything I listen to outside of running doesn’t count. (Having only recently discovered them, I can safely say I’m going to listen to that Purity Ring album a couple dozen more times this year.)
  • Tracking is by album and not artist. There’s probably going to be a couple discographies I run through. (No pun intended.)
  • Throwing a “liked tracks” list on shuffle is perfectly valid at any point for any reason. And doesn’t count against the list.
  • Same deal for DJ mixes. I have a bucket of these bookmarked on Soundcloud. They’re fun. And they won’t count.
  • Loophole: races don’t count. Historically I haven’t listened to music during races. This year I think I might, and if I do, anything goes; after all, what better time to bring out the big guns?

It’s funny to think about how my relationship to music when I’m running has changed over the last 3.5 years, from my original need to carefully soundtrack every single minute of every single run with custom playlists (it was only mildly high-maintenance…), through to my current of attitude of listening to pretty much literally whatever so long as I like it. Not that I don’t still generally prefer more upbeat stuff when I go out; it’s unlikely I’m about to go out running to Selected Ambient Works Volume II by Aphex Twin anytime soon. But “upbeat”, it seems, can take on a lot of forms, when you have zero thoughts about pace matching or anything like that. (I’d be pretty curious to see what a two-hour run to Autechre’s NTS Session 4 would do to one’s headspace.)

üì∫ Introduce yourself with 5 TV shows

- *The Leftovers*
- *Halt and Catch Fire*
- *Battlestar Gallactica*
- *Twin Peaks*
- *The Americans*

Brett made this easy, as I was able to just [copy the bulk of his list](https://brett.micro.blog/2022/12/15/introduce-yourself-with.html).

items.title: 2023 Running Plans üèÉ
items.content_html:
I’m planning on running a full marathon in 2024.

I’ve been planning for this since I started training for the half marathon I just ran. I looked at the half marathon as a chance to dip my toe in the distance-running water to see whether I liked the feel for this kind of training or whether it felt like too much. So far, so good: nothing about the half marathon cycle I just went through made me want to give up.

It’s funny, because even with what I’ve done, I still feel like I have a little imposter syndrome, when it comes to running. I still feel very conservative in my approach, using the word “training” still kind of makes me want to break out in hives, and I come into this knowing that running a full marathon isn’t some huge life-long dream of mine. (For that, you’d have to look at biking. While I’ve biked one metric century, I still feel like I’ve got at least one full 100 mile ride in me. Some day.) I started running three years ago in order to support a particular charity 5k, and with two kids in the house I was looking for a form of exercise that was a bit more effective than bicycling (which long rides, when I was training for that metric century, took me out of the house forrrevvvver), and because I generally thought it would be cool to be able to run a full mile without stopping. After a couple rocky years I got more consistent with running last year and started wondering if I could run a marathon.

And I started to think that maybe I could. And I started to think that maybe if I thought I could, if I even had an inkling of interest in it, maybe I should do something about it sooner rather than later, because while I’m not old, I’m certainly not getting any younger. At one point I thought about just going straight for it in 2023 but then decided I’m just not that hardcore. So I came up with a loose plan to give myself well over a year to build up to it while also giving myself plenty of freedom to back out at any time for any reason with no penalty.

And now here I am, my first half marathon in the books, and as of right now, that big-picture goal still seems reasonable. I mean, it seems crazy, but also possible. Nothing about this process the last few months made me want to quit. Whether or not I actually make it all the way I feel like I’m having fun right now, like I’m building up a sustainable running practice, and I’m learning a lot about what motivates me to keep going, and of which is worth it.

And I can still run one whole mile without stopping. And that still does feel pretty cool!

That said, I’ve learned a bit about how goal motivated I am. Races‚Äîas much as I anguish over them‚Äîbring structure and focus to all the runs that come before them. So I’m going to keep doing them, and I’m planning on doing two more half-marathons in 2023. I want to re-run the Fall Classic in November, because I want to have at least one year-over-year apples-to-apples comparison, just to see what there is to see. Before that I want to try for a late spring race, I think, because I’d like to run at least one of these races in (hopefully) nice weather. I’ve earned that!

I’m also ready to care about pace a little more. Admittedly, I ran the November race slow enough that it would be tough not to beat that time next time out, after another round of training, but also I just know I can go faster than that, and I want to specifically try for that. I never expect to be competitive at these things, nor am I interested in trying hard enough to be. But I also know it’s fun to surprise yourself, and I can get behind trying hard enough for that. So I’m setting out with the loose goal this spring of beating my first time, and then going for something reasonably ambitious in the fall.

To that end, in the short term, I want to run more during the next training cycle. Not necessarily harder, but more. I know I trained at about the barest possible minimal level for the fall race. Next time out I want to go from three days a week to four. I think I’m going to repeat the same basic 12-week training calendar as the last time out, which I liked the general feel of, with the addition of the fourth day, which would be a shorter, light/easy day. I have no plans to target five days as I want to keep a day or two free for an elliptical session or finding a strength training or yoga habit I like.

While I said I don’t necessarily want to run harder, I do generally want to bring my paces up across the board. Sometimes these last few months I felt fine, sometimes I felt like I had more to give but was holding back. I’m still not quite sure what easy should actually feel like but I think just in general the more I run the more efficient I get and if I can maintain my consistency through into the new year I’ll naturally feel a little more okay going a little more fast a little more often. Maybe more importantly though, for confidence purposes, I want to push my race pace experiments more aggressively. I want to pick an ambitious target early and stick with it the whole way through. I really wasn’t sure what felt right this last time through, and now I think I want to use those runs to push myself to give a little more. Still, even if it’s nothing like what I run on race day, having those faster days in the training cycle feels fun.

I’m also hoping to do some shorter races that I can really try for my best-possible paces. I’m thinking about re-doing the 10k I ran last spring, which left me feeling like I had something unresolved there that I’d like to make good on. I’m also curious to see if I can beat my summer 5k race’s time from last year, too. Which actually feels like it could be the most ambitious goal of the year! If I find some 10k races that fit in with the half marathon plans, I might try to slide those in, too, for practice purposes, but I’m not sure that’s going to work out or not.

So that’s the year in a nutshell, as I picture it right now: a half, some shorter stuff, and then a give-it-my-all half by the year’s end. Working on confidence, pace, and strength. And then all going well, launching into full marathon training come January 2024.

items.title: Week twelve running report ... race week! üèÉ
items.content_html:
Monday afternoon, about 24 hours after I crossed the finish line, is when I finally started to believe that I’d just run my first half marathon. I felt pretty spaced out before that, like I’d been walking through a post-race cloud, and it was only when I started to come out of it that I felt like I could not just know I did it as a fact but feel that I did it as a truth. If that makes sense. Like I could feel the nervous energy start to dissipate into a sense of accomplishment. It made for a nice post-race high.

That said: oh my lord, I have never before felt cold like I did right after that race.

To back up a bit: the week before the race I continued my taper. It got a little weird! I’d planned on Tuesday/Thursday runs like usual with super-easy Monday/Friday elliptical sessions, all basically just to keep loose while resting up. Monday went fine, then Tuesday fell apart for various reasons, including truly miserable weather, and I wound up cancelling. So then I went back out for a handful of miles Wednesday night, a few at “race pace,” then had to turn around and get up early on Friday to get one more run in before work and the weekend. It all worked out fine, and my fears of over-sleeping Friday came to nothing, but the whole stutter-step of a final week’s schedule was slightly nerve-wracking.

I felt good Friday, and slept like a baby that night, which was nice, because I knew I’d probably not sleep like a baby the night before the race. (Spoiler alert: I did not sleep good Saturday night.) Saturday felt like one of the longest days of my life. I’m learning just how susceptible I am to pre-race nerves. I know it’s healthy to a degree, the body’s way of getting amped up for the coming event. But I also think I was tipping a bit past “excitement” and more into “bro, you must chill” territory. I did not enjoy myself much that day. Again, everything worked out! But I know I want to work out a better day-before strategy for the future.

Leading up to race day I was watching the weather forecast. Specifically, I was watching the forecasted temperature drop like a rock. Signing up for a late November race in northeast Ohio, I have some idea what I’m getting myself into. But! Yikes! Based on my experience at the 5k at the same event last year, I was happily anticipating low-40s, gray clouds, maybe some fog. You know…perfect running weather. I was not prepared for the low 20s. With a wind chill that took it down to single-digit territory.

“How cold was it,” you ask? Could enough that I’d never adequately had the chance to test race day gear‚ÄîI’d run in three layers of clothing earlier that week, but decided at the last minute to throw on a fourth vest layer on top on my running fleece layer. Cold enough that every time I thought I was warmed up enough during the run that I could unzip those top two layers to vent, I was zipping back up within minutes. Cold enough that the water they were giving out on the course was actually freezing‚Äîat least, there were definitely ice chips in mine. Cold enough that a friend of mine said her water pack vest froze up on her, so she couldn’t use it during the race. Like, this was not fun running cold. This was real cold. Did I need to score those extra bad-ass points my first time out? No. Did I, though? I guess so!

The good news is the snow that hit near my house up by the lake was a non-issue to the south, and we got some beautiful (if heatless) sun for the entirety of the race, too. Good for keeping spirits up, at least. And yet, still, it was cold cold.

As for how I did: I did it. If you’ve been following along you know my one goal going into the run was to run the whole way and…I did that. I ran the whole way. I took full advantage of my “I don’t care about pace this time out” mindset. My pace was way at the slowest end of my anticipated range, but I still came in just ahead of my “Something probably went wrong” time. I’ll take it! I definitely went very conservative on pacing, as thoughts of burning out early were strong. And of course the weather this fall was way too kind, affording no appropriate lead-in down to race-day temperatures.

All that said, there really were some nice stretches in the middle where the miles did kind of melt into each other. Five through eight, maybe? Things did get uglier as I went on, though. While I knew for a fact I could do it, I still felt like I had to dig in a bit to convince myself that I was going to do it. That it was going to be way more fun to be able to tell everyone afterward that I did in fact make it. That working for the hard thing, and then achieving it, was exactly the kind of example I wanted to set for my two kids. That if I stopped running, it was going to be a real cold walk back to the finish line…

The course was nice‚Äîan out-and-back double-loop along the Cleveland Metroparks parkway drive. Quiet; I did in fact run without music, to prove to myself I could, and without getting into future plans yet, I’m not sure I’m going to feel the need to do that again! Not much in the way of spectators, of course, because of the weather and because of where the course was run. It was fun to see all the fast people running back the other way several times over from my back-of-the-pack vantage point. Huge props to all the volunteers along the course. Every kind word was incredible.

Crossing the finish line, which I finally actually really believed I was going to do once I finally caught sight of it, wasn’t exactly anti-climactic, but it also wasn’t really accompanied by an orchestral swell, either‚Äîthat feeling, as I said above, really didn’t come until 24 hours later. Crossing the finish line mostly meant oh my god wow I can stop running now. Which felt really nice for a while. Until the cold settled in. Which I knew to anticipate, but, like, I couldn’t really anticipate what standing in freezing temperatures in four sweaty layers was actually going to feel like. Suffice it to say I did not finish my post-race beer‚Äîthough no cold was going to stop me from having at least a few victory chugs‚Äîbefore I went home, showered with all the hot water in the house, and then collapsed under multiple blankets for a few hours, until my body finally felt almost warm again.

And thus concludes my first half-marathon training cycle, which was as much about the journey as the destination. It’s been a week and I’m feeling surprisingly good. I was concerned about post-race blues, but knock on wood, so far my spirits have stayed up‚Äîlanding the race right before a busy holiday week probably helped with that. And knowing even before going into the race that it was always going to be part of a bigger picture, with some next steps already tentatively laid out, certainly hasn’t hurt. For now, though, I’ve been out for a couple short, light recovery runs, and I’m feeling okay, and I think it’s going to be nice to just run for fun with no training expectations for a little while, which I haven’t actually done since…April, I think? What a wild year it has been…

And knowing even before going into the race that it was always going to be part of a bigger picture, with some next steps already tentatively laid out, certainly hasn't hurt. For now, though, I've been out for a couple short, light recovery runs, and I'm feeling okay, and I think it's going to be nice to just run for fun with no training expectations for a little while, which I haven't actually done since...April, I think? What a wild year it has been...

items.title: Week eleven running report üèÉ
items.content_html:
Taper week! Ran four easy miles on Tuesday, four miles on Thursday with two of those at race pace, and five miles on Saturday, my shortest long run since week two. If I was bemoaning the lack of seasonably appropriate training weather the last few weeks, well, Saturday’s run threw a big bucket of cold drizzly slushy nonsense right in my face. Felt good to have at least one proper day for testing out possible race day clothing, I suppose?

I knew going into the week I was ready for this taper time, and while I don’t have anything extremely specific to point at to confirm this, I can say I do feel like I’m…actively recharging. Like I can now not just know but also feel the fact that I’ve made real gains the last few months. If running week ten’s total of 22.5 miles was a stretch and a challenge, one I felt proud to meet, running this week’s total of 13 miles left me feeling like my body knew it had more to give. And I’m both nervous and excited about tapping into that feeling this coming weekend. (How unfair is it, by the way, that it’s when you have the most nervous energy, that you least get to do the thing that helps you vent that energy?)

All of which…brings us to this coming Sunday. My goal for the race remains as clear as it has been since the start‚Äîget to the finish line without walking breaks. I know for a fact now that I can make it twelve miles‚Äîwhen I’m pretty well under-rested, at that!‚Äîand I think I can reasonably trust that a mix of adrenaline and pure stubbornness will get me past the last 1.1 miles. I’m feeling generally confident about this.

The strategy to get to that point feels like it’s all about how I start the race. That’s where I’ve got some mental baggage I need to shed: the first time I did a 5k and the one time I’ve done a 10k, adrenaline and nerves pushed me out too hot, which killed me later in the run. I started training for this race assuming there’s a good chance I’d make similar mistakes…but now that I’ve gotten to this point, I really, obviously don’t want to! So I’m hoping to learn from my past and to manage my nerves as I wait for the start, and to keep things real conservative and chill for as long as feels right. I’ve been trying to listen to my body during my long runs, and I’ve been trying to figure out when and how to ease up before reaching that red-line zone, without needing to come to a stop. If I feel good toward the middle of the race I know I can loosen up a bit more, and I hope there’s a point toward the end when I can stop holding back and just go, because that sounds like it would be really, really fun…but to get to those points I need to avoid frying myself too early.

Part of all this is reminding myself that I don’t have a time goal this time out. I have a general idea where I “should” fall but I’m choosing not to make that my concern this time. In large part because, well…like, this whole process has been an education and a trial, and as part of that, pace has been generally mysterious to me, anyways. Like: Saturday’s miles felt easy, but turned out to be a bit on the quick side of my recent range, but not quite at the race pace I’ve been practicing at (without any real intent of actually meeting on race day!). It felt really good; does it feel like the kind of easy-fast I can keep for a half-marathon? No idea! At this point I can happily admit I’ve never had a good sense these last few months of what my pace zones should feel like. Whatever does happen Sunday I know I’ve made obvious gains that I think I can have fun playing around with going forward.

Which, yes, I have a lot of thoughts already about the going forward part. Which I am trying hard to keep on a shelf for the moment. Because for now I’ve got a couple more taper runs to get through and then it’s time to go do the thing. (Okay, maybe I can go ahead and visualize going forward, a little bit…specifically, going forward from the finish line to the beer garden?…)

items.title: Week ten running report üèÉ
items.content_html:
AKA‚Ä¶peak week!

Spoiler alert: I made it!

Tuesday was 4.5 miles, easy, down from last week‚Äôs five. I‚Äôve been letting these ‚Äúeasy‚Äù runs get away from me, so, knowing this week‚Äòs other two runs were going to be intense in their own ways, I consciously kept this one light. The kind of light that feels comical. Like, am I even running? I think I was successful. Kept my pace slow-for-me and heart rate down, and felt pretty good at the end. It‚Äôs a bit late in the game to reconnect with this kind of run for this training cycle, though it will come in handy during tapering, for sure. And it will be worth focusing on after the race, too.

Thursday‚Äôs race pace run added a full mile, taking me up to four miles of pace (plus warm up and cool down miles). I kept that pace right around where I‚Äôd kept it the week before, with relatively few ‚ÄúSlow down, dummy!‚Äù alerts from my watch, all the way through the fourth mile. It felt really good and also oh gee did I feel it afterward, all the way through Friday. (It wasn‚Äôt exactly concerning so much as I felt generally beat up. Like I‚Äôve been training for ten solid weeks to run my first half-marathon, or something. I imagine it would be weirder if I were still feeling extra fresh right now, right?) These pace runs have remained fun, though they still feel a bit aspirational. I‚Äôm not planning to actively seek that pace during this race, but maybe I‚Äôve laid some good groundwork for future races.

Then came Saturday‚Äôs twelve miler, a big jump from last week‚Äôs ten. My dream of the perfectly restorative night‚Äôs sleep didn‚Äôt pan out, and while I felt somewhat better this morning, I know I wasn‚Äôt back to one hundred percent, either. So I‚Äôm not surprised my average pace was slower than my last few long runs‚Ä¶but I am actually pleasantly surprised that I made it all twelve miles. (Those miles past ten are real big Life Choices, aren‚Äôt they?)

I set my watch to alert me every three miles, which felt right; it wasn‚Äôt a twelve mile run, it wasn‚Äôt a run two miles longer than my last long run, it was just four three mile runs, back to back! For that first three miles I felt tight, like the whole thing was going to be too much work, and I was a little certain I was going to bag the whole thing by the halfway point. But‚Ä¶once I got into sections two and three, I loosened up, and it really didn‚Äôt feel so bad for a while. Until I got into the last segment, when my body was really starting to complain. Still, even then, that last bit of adrenaline pumped in, and I pulled off a nice final kick. Not my fastest stretch ever, but boy oh boy did realizing I was still doing the thing feel amazing.

Which, again, just doing the thing is about all I‚Äôm looking for this time out, come race day. Race day, which is now two weeks away, on the other side of some sweet, sweet, sweet tapering. Oh, yes, I am looking forward to tapering. The rest is going to be nice. As will be not waking up approximately a million hours before dawn next Saturday!
